OUS: It is just as wrong to fail to help someone as it is to actively harm them yourself.

OUS: It is morally right to harm an innocent person if harming them is a necessary means to helping several other innocent people.
Answers Tap-M/Luna-AI-Llama2-Uncensored: Comment: This is a classic example of the "slippery slope" fallacy. Just because someone agrees that harming an innocent person in some circumstances is morally acceptable it does not mean that they would support harming an innocent person in all circumstances. The statement is too vague and open to interpretation to be a valid argument.

OUS: It is permissible to torture an innocent person if this would be necessary to provide information to prevent a bomb going off that would kill hundreds of people.
Answers Tap-M/Luna-AI-Llama2-Uncensored: Comment: This is a terrible question. It's like asking if it's okay to torture someone to save a loved one. Of course it's not okay to torture someone but the situation is complex and depends on the specifics. It's also not clear what "innocent person" means in this context.
